reviewText:
what are you looking for here? honestly you are looking for a review??? this game does not even need one, it is my childhood and i am sure everyone who was born in 1990s should have played this too but here is a little review for other developers and people who are wondered what this game is:

it does not have frost bite engine but it has fully destructive world

it does not have super graphics but there is no graphic glitches

it does not have season pass or DLC but it has 3 episodes with 9 levels each

it does not have microtransactions but you can upgrade your jet with what you earn in game

it does not even have a trailer, it was never announced in E3 but every true gamer knows it

it does not cost $60 but back in 1990s there was a freeware version of this game (still exists) and it is like demo which gives you access to episode 1 completely

final verdict: you see now? this game is much more completed for $5 than any other $60 game out there which givse you only half of the game and rest is DLC.

now why you even looked at this review? like there is anything wrong with this game? you are doubt to buy and play it? then get out of here!

reviewText:
Hi there!
Really loved that game and spent hours and hours and hours...

I've been quite disapointed that mouse control did not work with this steam version and the ship moves very slow using the keyboard.
However, there's a fix, I'd like to share:
Within the Folder
{Steaminstallationfolder}\Steam\SteamApps\common\Raptor Call of the Shadows\Raptor - Call of the Shadows\nEdit the file Setup.ini and change
Control=0
to
Control=1

-> Mouse works and ship moves twice as fast as with keyboard controls.
Eventually feels like it did in the good ol' days!

Have fun and indulge in nostalgia!

reviewText:
Likely among the best of the DOS-era top-down shooters bef, second only to Tyrian in my opinion. Has a fast pace, a career type mode where have to purchase upgrades. Not a absurdly long game by todays standards, but quite a solid title and a must play if you purchased the Anthology. Solid 256-color VGA graphics, digitized sounds (!), and a host of little touches make this game a joy to play and add depth.

Only downside, is this has no interaction with Steam or modernization at all which is a shame because achievements would have been an awesome modern touch.

It kicks me square in my childhood, speaking of which... My brother and I were so excited when we got this game back then, that we fought it out over who played first. My front tooth lost, and the parents were not all too amused.

Ahh, the memories.

reviewText:
10/10

It's you against the world. Thousands of planes, helicopters, tanks, boats, and stationary guns, and nothing standing between them and you except an arsenal of ridiculous weapons and your own twitch skill. Elite mode is basically suicide, and your keyboard will not survive. It's played with arrow keys + ctrl-alt-space, which is a little clunky but you get used to it.

Raptor survives the test of time, released more than 20 years ago, and the polish that Apogee put into it really shows. The pixellated graphics are skilfully-rendered and it's very clear what's happening, which is definitely a good thing since the game is basically a bullet hell. Skillfully using the situational weapons you buy and find is critical to keeping down the flood of enemies so that you aren't overwhelmed. Every enemy and building destroyed yields money at the end of the mission that can be used to fix up your top-of-the-line fighter with shields, radar, conventional missiles, auto-tracking miniguns, experimental EMP waves, and eventually my favorite weapon, the laser that fires twin beams of azure fire.

The levels initially follow a simple progression: Fight off a few enemies, pick up a weapon, use it to maul your way past the rest of the level while trying to avoid damage and make your end-of-level repair bill as low as you can. Eventually you'll fight a boss (Known to the devs as a Battle Cow
date: strangely), which is usually an immense airship bristling with weapons. If things get too hectic, there's a pricey but room-clearing Megabomb just a tap of the spacebar away. It destroys everything onscreen (Dealing heavy damage to bosses) but takes a few seconds to go off (As it floats to the middle of the screen) adding a bit of strategic depth on timing and being able to expect yourself to get shitcanned a few seconds before it actually happens. A bit later in the game, some of the original bosses make appearances as mini-bosses which always calls for a hectic all-out DPS-dump. Take too long and you'll be fighting off the mini-boss at the same time as the level's standard enemies. Later, the bosses will manifest as humungous, multi-turreted ground-based fortresses, which have immense health bars and require a good amount of timing to cut down.\n\nA lot of the weapons are designed to be worthless in certain situations, picking the right one is always the key to survival. A couple of the weapons are total duds, but the small handful of always active" weapons are always a safe bet. Save up for the auto-tracking minigun and prepare for a ♥♥♥♥ing good time because its DPS is huge and it shreds stuff to your sides
hoursPlayed: quite useful if you've only got a pinprick of health left and a giant boss is obliteraing the airspace directly in front of it.\n\nIt's not nostalgia
voteText: it's just damn good: Raptor is tough as nails and the harder difficulties will probably beat your ♥♥♥. Do yourself a favor and pick this up."

reviewText: Classic Shoot'Em Up fun! It's the 1994 DOS version of Raptor and it runs on DOSBox. This means you will have to edit some config files to get the right aspect ratio and to enable mouse controls. There is also the 2015 Edition of Raptor on Steam. Avoid it! It's a pretty buggy port. The 1994 Classic Edition is the version of Raptor you want to get.

reviewText:
This game.... I have the floppies on my gaming shelf. A classic top-down scrolling shooter!!

Good sound effects (I'm pretty sure they are as close to the original as possible) and great nostalgia. Music seems to be fully digitized and edited, therefore not the original midi. There are sound parts that have edited out too. Nothing that detracts from the game overall.

Here’s a quick video to see the gameplay. Also check out how quickly the stages load… the x86 days where we had to wait what seemed like an eternity for the game to load are certainly a thing of the past!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6AbjW1BaB7c

reviewText: GOD, I LOVE THIS GAME!  Brings back so many memories... The only thing is, for some reason I haven't yet figured out, it resets my progress after the final stage of Bravo Sector. Other than that, it's every gamer's dream!\n\nA word of caution for all: This game was developed before screen rotation was introduced, so be careful not to press Fire (Ctrl), Weapon Select (Alt) and movement (Arrow key) all at the same time. If you make this mistake, as I did, the screen will rotate on you and ruin your game. Some windows setups have the option of locking/disabling screen rotation, but the best (and smart) thing to do is save your game after every mission. This will save you alot of headaches.

reviewText:
Given the amount of janky ♥♥♥ ports of old games floating around on Steam these days, it's refreshing to discover that Raptor: Call of the Shadows seems plagued with none of the usual complications. No window-sizing issues, no compatibility problems, not even the slightest  hint of input lag (I'm looking at you, Age of Empires II) - I've read of some people having a harder time with the 2015 Edition, but from my experience, the Classic Edition is flawless from a functionality standpoint.

As for the game itself - well, video games have come a long way in 22 years, and you won't find a much better barometer for exactly how far than Raptor. The levels are ugly - they can get incredibily cluttered to the point where it's hard to tell what is even happening, the colour palette gets very dark and murky in places, sometimes to the point where enemies are difficult to distinguish from the background scenery, and both of these things combined with some pretty poor colour contrast means that the inclusion of the occasional night time mission was a very, very bad idea.

The upgrade system is fairly extensive, but ultimately pointless. You can afford arguably the best gun in the game (which costs less than two-tenths of the most expensive gun available), the Auto-Track Mini-Gun, before the end of the first sector, which is to the games difficulty curve what Ivan Milat was to European backpackers.

But ultimately, nitpicking a 20 year old game aside, if you enjoyed the game way back when and are the nostalgic type, there is enough here to recommend, especially for 5 bucks.

This is how Steam ports of old games should be done.

reviewText:
I remember I only had a chapter of Raptor, and I was already frustrated with the shareware model by that time. Now I have it complete, and I have them all!

As with every game in this collection, the graphics will look worse than you remember, and the music and sounds will be crappier too. Plus it will be harder than you remember (it's a reminder of how casual we are now, or how age has affected our reflexes),

Always loved these games, and Raptor was a huge upgrade from 1942, the other game I had access to at that time.

reviewText:
I remember bought box version of this game at my childhood.
That was one of my most pleased days in memory.
Now here I am, reviewing my very good-nostalgia.

Tell you the truth, actually raptor is not the best shooter game,
obviously not now but also was back then, when I'm young.
At the time, something like Raiden 3 at the arcade center was better,
ofcourse it's matter of opinion, though.

But still, Raptor was among the most fun shooter games back then, and you don't really often
see well-made shooter game which native to PC. Actually Raptor is only game in shooter
category I remember on PC, so it has it's own special worth too.

Stages are all up-scrolling while shoot and blast endless wave of enemy fighters,
ships, tanks, buildings. I tell you this, it's actually quite repetitive.
But it gives you more than enough stimulate to keep playing, and game is spiced up with
it's upgrading feature, where you can buy equipment and upgrade your fighter between
any stages with your money which hard-earned by destroying things.

Graphics are cool and well detailed despite of it's old-ages. I'm sure it'll please your eyes.

And Sound, it's something I can't say it's really good. But in other hand, it's also not that bad,
atleast it will not hurt your ear I guess.

Overall, This is a game which proved it's own nostalgia is not just an illusion,
and not so many games from my nostalgia get that statement.

If you like shooter game and fond of it, I definitely recommend this game.
If not? Well... it's still worth to give it a try!

reviewText:
Wow, I remember this being a neat game back in the day. But man, today, it plays like aaass.

The ship movement feels really floaty. It accelerates fast, and it keeps moving a bit more when you let go of the movement key. So you can either do large but imprecise sweeping movements, or small twitchy movements, which are not helpful.

The screen area is too small for the kinds of jittery moves the enemies do - there's little room to dodge, so you'll take damage no matter what once the tanks with homing shots start coming in.

The player's collision box does not match the shape of the plane, and is about 50% larger - very misleading to someone used to playing bullet hell shooters. The fact that your hitbox is so big means that any sort of fine maneuvering, like squeezing between streams of bullets, is just not worth it.

The ship health is directly tied to player money. The worse you do, the more you'll have to spend to refill your health, and the less you'll have to buy weapons. The stages get more and more unforgiving, and there's no way to go back and farm up some extra money. So if you don't perform really well, might as well just reload and try again.

And as a final F* you: if you take too much damage, you lose all your weapons. Of course it doesn't tell you in any way. There is literally no point continuing the game when this happens, and if you accidentally save, your game is ruined.

reviewText:
Raptor: Call of The Shadows Versions is an Awesome MS-DOS Game, I'm a Professional at this game & I grew up with this Old DOS Classic.

Your engine's turbines roar as you scream out of the sky. Startled troops look up just in time to see your wing cannons blaze. You feel the plane buck slightly as your missiles streak toward their targets. A flash in the distance tells you that they have done their job and so have you. MegaCorp pays well, for those good enough to survive. They call you into the shadows with dreams of wealth, and you answer, the only way you know how.

With 15 Different Weapons, 3 Different Power-Ups, 27 Levels (9 in each Episode) & 3 Different Episodes to play, Raptor: Call of the Shadows is an MS-DOS Classic that would make you want to relive your Childhood Gaming days again and again!
